image.altText: A woman standing inside an office and looking serious while holding several thick documents.

image.altText: Hands using a laptop at a table

image.altText: Steven Bradbury

title.children: Australia's transition to a cashless society is underway — but not everyone wins when we get rid of cash

image.altText: An elderly woman smiling and holding weights in her hands.

items.synopsis: Catherina van der Linden, who is believed to be Australia's oldest living person, will celebrate her 111th birthday this week.

title.children: Catherina is turning 111 years old and still hits the gym up to three times a week

image.altText: A man sitting at a desk with his hands clasped together

image.altText: Composite of a black and white photo of a man holding a guitar with an older man to his right and older woman to his left.

image.altText: A blond woman waves, she is wearing a red scarf around her neck.

items.synopsis: Following record-breaking levels of crime and violence in Alice Springs last summer, NT Police say this year will look "markedly different".

image.altText: A young girl sits in a booster seat in the rear seat of a car.

items.synopsis: Stella is about to turn seven, making her legally able to sit in the front seat, but she won't be graduating out of her booster seat any time soon.

title.children: When is it safe for a child to sit in the front seat? Kidsafe urges parents to rethink child restraints

image.altText: A woman with dark hair holding a newborn baby under a striped blanket and a young woman with blonde hair holding a newborn

items.synopsis: Telehealth is revolutionising medicine in remote areas, but one obstetrician says entrusting the delivery of a baby to "pure luck" in Australia during 2023 "isn't good enough".

title.children: No privacy, no pain relief and no specialist: Mothers traumatised by unplanned telehealth births

image.altText: A woman in a bright red sweater and blue jeans texts on her smartphone

image.altText: A beach with large swells and high rises in the background.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

image.altText: A young woman sits up on a stretcher

items.synopsis: A 23-year-old bank teller caught up in a siege inspired the psychological term Stockholm syndrome. But 50 years later, experts say Kristin's story is totally misunderstood.

image.altText: A map of Victoria showing the percentage of residents overqualified for their jobs by suburb.

image.altText: Woolworths sign

items.synopsis: Grocery giant Woolworths says high inflation has seen its annual profit rise to $1.62 billion, and warns food inflation is set to continue. The ASX and Australian dollar gain thanks to stronger commodity prices.

title.children: Woolworths reports $1.62b profit on higher prices, ASX and Australian dollar driven higher by iron ore prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of people on the aged pension will decrease in coming decades, even though more Australians are getting older according to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The government's latest Intergenerational Report, which projects outlooks for the economy and the budget over the next 40 years, will be released in full tomorrow by Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The report shows the reliance on the age pension will reduce, because of growing superannuation balances. Mr Chalmers says it shows that super is achieving its purpose of providing retirement support. "Spending on the pension, age pension and service pension will go down from about 2.3 percent of the economy last year to 2 percent at end of IGR period. that is an absolutely stunning outcome when you consider the aging of our population." It's important to note though that tax breaks associated with superannuation will exceed pension spending by the 2040s and reach 2.4 per cent of GDP by 2063. Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says pension spending to fall

children.content: The number of people on the aged pension will decrease in coming decades, even though more Australians are getting older according to Treasurer Jim Chalmers.
The government's latest Intergenerational Report, which projects outlooks for the economy and the budget over the next 40 years, will be released in full tomorrow by Treasurer Jim Chalmers.
The report shows the reliance on the age pension will reduce, because of growing superannuation balances.
Mr Chalmers says it shows that super is achieving its purpose of providing retirement support.

"Spending on the pension, age pension and service pension will go down from about 2.3 percent of the economy last year to 2 percent at end of IGR period. that is an absolutely stunning outcome when you consider the aging of our population."
It's important to note though that tax breaks associated with superannuation will exceed pension spending by the 2040s and reach 2.4 per cent of GDP by 2063.
Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's high property prices means first home buyers need to save for a house deposit for at least 16 years on average, and 12 years for an apartment. That's according to financial comparison website Finder. Finder says that would mean saving nearly $300,000 for a house deposit and $188,523 for a unit. Home loans expert at Finder, Richard Whitton, says many first home buyers simply can't afford to save such big deposits. “Wage growth over the past few decades simply hasn’t kept up with skyrocketing property prices. “Saving up enough for a deposit, especially when the cost of everything from food, energy, and insurance – not to mention rent – is rising, is a big barrier to overcome. “Buying a home is becoming increasingly out of reach for many Aussies.” New South Wales is the most expensive place to buy with households need to save for 20 years on average for a house deposit of $470,660. You can see why many people will never be able to get on the property ladder. The Northern Territory and Western Australia were the best places to save for a home deposit, with NT households needing to save for an average of 8 years for a $151,584 house deposit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First home buyers need to save for more than a decade to buy a home

children.content: Australia's high property prices means first home buyers need to save for a house deposit for at least 16 years on average, and 12 years for an apartment.
That's according to financial comparison website Finder.
Finder says that would mean saving nearly $300,000 for a house deposit and $188,523 for a unit.
Home loans expert at Finder, Richard Whitton, says many first home buyers simply can't afford to save such big deposits.
“Wage growth over the past few decades simply hasn’t kept up with skyrocketing property prices.
“Saving up enough for a deposit, especially when the cost of everything from food, energy, and insurance – not to mention rent – is rising, is a big barrier to overcome.
“Buying a home is becoming increasingly out of reach for many Aussies.”
New South Wales is the most expensive place to buy with households need to save for 20 years on average for a house deposit of $470,660.
You can see why many people will never be able to get on the property ladder.
The Northern Territory and Western Australia were the best places to save for a home deposit, with NT households needing to save for an average of 8 years for a $151,584 house deposit.

props.alt: Table showing how long households need to save for home deposits

children.content: Home deposits
(Finder, ABS, CoreLogic)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has announced a review of competition policy to make it more difficult for big companies to take over smaller firms. Assistant Minister for Competition Andrew Leigh says Australia's productivity growth has slowed over the past decade and reduced competition has contributed. The review will look at competition laws, policies and institutions and a competition task force has been established in Treasury. The review will look at: Proposals put forward by the Australian      Competition and Consumer Commission around merger reform, as well as other      competition law issues Options for coordinated reform with states      and territories, to be progressed through the Council on Federal Financial      Relations Non-compete and related clauses that      restrict workers from shifting to a better-paying job Providing advice on competition issues      raised by new technologies, the net zero transformation and growth in the      care economy Former ACCC chair Rod Sims and current ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottleib have called for stronger laws to stop mergers that entrench market power. "We always need to get the balance right on merger reform," said Mr Leigh. "The ACCC's proposals ... are serious proposals deserving of careful scrutiny"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Review of competition policy

children.content: The federal government has announced a review of competition policy to make it more difficult for big companies to take over smaller firms.
Assistant Minister for Competition
Andrew Leigh
says Australia's productivity growth has slowed over the past decade and reduced competition has contributed.
The review will look at competition laws, policies and institutions and a competition task force has been established in Treasury.
The review will look at:
Proposals put forward by the Australian      Competition and Consumer Commission around merger reform, as well as other      competition law issues
Options for coordinated reform with states      and territories, to be progressed through the Council on Federal Financial      Relations
Non-compete and related clauses that      restrict workers from shifting to a better-paying job
Providing advice on competition issues      raised by new technologies, the net zero transformation and growth in the      care economy
Former ACCC chair Rod Sims and current ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottleib have called for stronger laws to stop mergers that entrench market power.
"We always need to get the balance right on merger reform," said Mr Leigh.
"The ACCC's proposals ... are serious proposals deserving of careful scrutiny"

image.altText: A South Korean coastguard officer inspects a red and white jet ski that sits on a small trailer behind a green fence.

items.synopsis: With five barrels of petrol, binoculars and a compass, Kwon Pyong navigates a jet ski more than 300 kilometres across the Yellow Sea from Shandong to Incheon.

title.children: 'He refilled the petrol on the ride': Chinese activist flees country on jet ski

image.altText: John Farnham.

items.synopsis: John Farnham says he a grateful and happy man as he marks the one-year anniversary of a 12-hour surgery to remove a cancerous tumour from his mouth.

title.children: 'Luckiest man alive': Music legend John Farnham gives health update

image.altText: A composite photo zooming in on a small, white fish with hands.

items.synopsis: A species of fish not seen since the Macarena was top of the pop charts is believed to have been spotted in deep waters off Tasmania — and scientists say it could be a symptom of the warming waters effect on species distribution.

title.children: Is this an elusive fish not seen in 27 years? Scientists think it is
